item.title: Nothing to see here, says Boris Johnson over flat costs investigation
item.description: Boris Johnson is facing an investigation into how a refurbishment bill was initially covered.

item.title: NHS England boss Stevens to step down this summer
item.description: After seven years in the job Sir Simon now becomes a life peer, the government says.

item.title: Gaunt Navalny attacks Putin as network is disbanded
item.description: President Putin's arch-critic appears after a hunger strike, as his team say they are being destroyed.

item.title: Grenfell: Campaigners vow to fight fire safety bill
item.description: Campaigners say "a generation of homeowners" face financial ruin after government wins Commons vote.

item.title: Jon Snow to leave Channel 4 News after 32 years
item.description: The long-serving journalist says it is "time to move on" after "three incredible decades".

item.title: Larne: Cars destroyed in arson attack on police officer's home
item.description: A line of inquiry is the possible involvement of the South East Antrim UDA, a paramilitary gang.

item.title: Killed community police officer last seen walking dog
item.description: The death of Julia James is being treated as murder after her body was found in woodland.

item.title: Biden pitches 'once in a generation investment' to Congress
item.description: The president lays out jobs, education and social care plans in a televised address to Congress.

item.title: Body found in Thames after boy's Tower Bridge fall
item.description: The body was recovered from the River Thames by marine units on Wednesday afternoon.

item.title: West Bengal: India state elections go ahead as deaths hit record high
item.description: Voters in the state of West Bengal go to the polls despite a surge in coronavirus infections.

item.title: Fishmongers' Hall attack: Prison boss tricked by Usman Khan, inquest hears
item.description: A prison's counter-terrorism head says he accepted Usman Khan's explanation about his bulky coat.

item.title: Ronan Keating and Jermaine Jenas join The One Show permanently
item.description: The pair will join Alex Jones on the BBC programme's sofa, each co-presenting for part of the week.

item.title: eBay launches new trainer authentication scheme
item.description: A new authentication scheme is launching in the UK to help spot counterfeit trainers.

item.title: Kate and William's 10 years of marriage in pictures
item.description: The past decade has seen the duke and duchess travel the world, work with charities and raise a family.

item.title: Gold Â£10,000 coin weighing 22lb produced at Royal Mint in Llantrisant
item.description: The 8in-wide (20cm) coin took 400 hours to produce - including four days of polishing.

item.title: The midnight league blending faith and sport
item.description: A new pilot giving young Muslims the chance to play sport during Ramadan.

item.title: 'My doctor prescribed rambling for lockdown anxiety'
item.description: An 84-year-old widower expected to receive medication after he felt isolated during the pandemic.

item.title: Lisa Arthurs: 'My daughter was crying out for help'
item.description: Gabrielle Connolly was waiting for counselling when she died from a drug-related incident.

item.title: Silverdale stink: 'My house and children's toys all smell of landfill'
item.description: Residents living near a landfill site say their physical and mental health is suffering.

item.title: The Troubles: Searching for the 'angel' who saved my life
item.description: Peter was shot and paralysed during Northern Ireland's Troubles. He is now hoping to find Betsy, the nurse who helped him through that time. But it has been more than 40 years without any contact.

item.title: Covid in India: Sikh temple offers drive-through oxygen
item.description: More than 1,000 people have used the service being offered by one Gurdwara in Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: Back to the office? Science reveals best desks to nab
item.description: Where you sit in an open-plan office can determine how content and productive you feel, researchers find.

item.title: PMQs: Five Boris Johnson claims fact-checked
item.description: Investigating claims about flat renovations, vaccines and misleading statements.

item.title: India Covid-19: Deadly second wave spreads from cities to small towns
item.description: The virus is spreading to remote corners of India where healthcare is poor and the crisis under-reported.

item.title: 2021 elections: A simple guide to the Scottish, Welsh and local elections
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: Richard Okorogheye: Prank callers told best friend they found his body
item.description: Richard Okorogheye's best friend Hala Mohamed explains the events following Richard's disappearance.

item.title: DUP: Who are the leadership contenders?
item.description: BBC News NI looks at three names being tipped as possible successors to Arlene Foster.

item.title: Line Of Duty: 'My favourite thing is reading the wild fan theories'
item.description: Martin Compston, who plays DI Steve Arnott, reveals what happens off-screen on the hit drama.

item.title: Housing: 'Trying to buy in this market is painful'
item.description: UK property transactions in March 2021 were at their highest level since records began in 2005, according to the HMRC.

item.title: They are killing our forest, Brazilian tribe warns
item.description: The Awa, who have been called "the most threatened tribe on earth", face fresh challenges in Brazil.

item.title: Zac Easter: He left his brain behind to save others from his fate
item.description: Zac Easter killed himself at the age of 24, having suffered for years from a debilitating disease caused by the sport he loved.

item.title: The 'forgotten' Afghan refugees taking their own lives
item.description: Many Afghan refugees who spent years stranded in Indonesia awaiting resettlement have lost hope.

item.title: Why virtual away days may be here to stay
item.description: Firms have been holding away days online to boost morale and team sprit during the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: How the UK has been getting jabs to remote territories
item.description: Since early January, 250,000 Covid vaccines doses have been administered in British Overseas Territories.

item.title: Executives at failed European Super League clubs forced to quit Premier League roles
item.description: Executives at clubs involved in the failed European Super League are forced to resign from advisory roles at the Premier League.

item.title: Springboard for Arteta or redemption for Emery - are things about to get worse for Arsenal?
item.description: A springboard for Mikel Arteta? Or the opportunity of redemption for Villarreal boss Unai Emery? And just how do the records of Arsenal's current and former boss compare?

item.title: Marcus Armitage sets a world record for farthest golf shot into moving car
item.description: Watch golfer Marcus Armitage set a new world record of 303 yards for the farthest golf shot hit into a moving car

item.title: Five key moments from Biden's first speech to Congress
item.description: From shattering a glass ceiling to racial justice reforms - here were the key moments.

item.title: President Biden's first 100 days as president fact-checked
item.description: Joe Biden has been US president for 100 days - we look at claims he has made during his first months.

item.title: Biden 100 days: Is US more or less unified under President Biden?
item.description: Americans weigh in on the president's first 100 days in office.

item.title: Biden speech: Are Americans happy with Biden's first 100 days?
item.description: Members of our Ask America panel praise Biden's Covid response but call for more bipartisanship.

item.title: Tim Scott: Republican senator who gave rebuttal speech to Biden
item.description: Tim Scott, who delivered the rebuttal to the president, is the only black Republican Senator.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Northern Ireland is the latest part of the UK to lift some of the restrictions designed to stop the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: International travel: The green list, red list and quarantine rules
item.description: An NHS app is being adapted to be used as a Covid passport for people holidaying abroad.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: What are the Indian, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: Cases are being found in the UK and the changes the virus is undergoing are concerning.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - but big celebrations with lots of guests are some way off.

item.title: Why India's Covid crisis matters to the whole world
item.description: The situation in India is a bleak reminder that none of us will be safe until everyone is safe.
